unnormalised: What are some beneficial government schemes for education in India?
normalised: What are some beneficial government schemes for education in India?

unnormalised: Well, the Indian govt. runs several schemes to help students out! One of the most popular is the "Sarva Shiksha Abhiyan" (SSA), launched in 2001. Its main goal is to provide free and compulsory education to all children aged 6-14 yrs. The SSA has really helped improve enrollment rates, especially in rural areas and for girls. Plus, you have the "Rashtriya Madhyamik Shiksha Abhiyan" (RMSA), which focuses on secondary education - basically, classes 9th and 10th.
normalised: Well, the Indian government runs several schemes to help students out! One of the most popular is the "Sarva Shiksha Abhiyan" (S-S-A), launched in two thousand one. Its main goal is to provide free and compulsory education to all children aged six to fourteen years. The S-S-A has really helped improve enrollment rates, especially in rural areas and for girls. Plus, you have the "Rashtriya Madhyamik Shiksha Abhiyan" (R-M-S-A), which focuses on secondary education - basically, classes ninth and tenth.

unnormalised: Then there's the "National Scholarship Portal" (NSP), which is like a one-stop shop for various scholarship programs. Students can apply for scholarships offered by the central govt., state govts., and even UGC approved institutions, all in one place. For example, the "Central Sector Scheme of Scholarship for College and University Students" offers financial assistance to deserving students who score above 80% in their Class 12 exams. This definitely helps ease the financial burden, especially for students from economically weaker sections.

unnormalised: Lastly, don't forget the "Pradhan Mantri Uchchatar Shiksha Abhiyan" (PM-USHA), which aims to improve the overall quality of higher education in the country. It provides funding to state universities and colleges to upgrade their infrastructure and faculty. These schemes, among others, are really crucial for making education more accessible and equitable for all. You can find more details on the MHRD website too. Hope this helps!
